report_title: Carpet and Floor Covering Distributors Industry Report
executive_summary: The Carpet and Floor Covering Distributors industry includes companies that wholesale carpet, wood tile and other materials used to cover existing floors. Primarily, this industry focuses on the distribution of installed carpets and area rugs, with those products generating the majority of industry revenue. Over the five years to 2022, this industry has struggled due to a combination of waning downstream demand and volatile input costs. Most significantly, at the height of the COVID-19 (coronavirus) pandemic in 2020, the world price of cotton plummeted, causing industry input costs to fall. However, due to the high price-based competition of the industry, distributors were forced to reduce prices, leading to a significant revenue decrease, while industry profit remained stable. Additionally, while economic recovery in 2021 supported industry revenue growth, surging home prices are expected to cause housing starts and home renovations to drop off in 2022. Residential construction, including both new homes and renovations of existing homes, is a significant driver of industry demand because many new homes install carpeting, and renovations may involve converting the floors through the use of floor coverings. As a result of this decline, industry revenue is expected to fall an estimated 2.1% in 2022.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Over the five years to 2022, the industry has experienced a moderate level of revenue volatility, as the COVID-19 (coronavirus) pandemic has disrupted construction markets and affected commodity prices. In 2020, the pandemic alone. This downward pressure on the industry, coupled with the disruption of the pandemic, has outweighed positive demand trends during the period. As a result, industry revenue is expected to decline at an annualized rate of 0.8% to $34.6 billion over the five years to 2022.

Following the first year of the pandemic, the economy began recovering, which spurred downstream demand growth. The pandemic has also contributed to more people moving out of cities and into suburban areas due to opportunities for office workers to work remotely. This resulted in a surge in housing starts and home sales in 2021. However, this trend is expected to quickly wane in 2022 as home prices skyrocket. As a result, housing starts are expected to decline in 2022, contributing to industry revenue falling 2.1% the same year.

In addition to construction trends, the industry is often affected by disposable income levels and consumer taste and preferences. Currently, wood floors are in higher demand than carpets among home buyers. According to 2020 data from the National Association of Realtors, 54.0% of home buyers are willing to pay higher prices for a home with hardwood floors (latest data available). This trend has posed a mild threat to industry operations because installed carpet carries a higher price tag than area rugs, which would be necessary in homes with hardwood floors.

Given the wide variety of industry products, the industry has a low level of market share concentration. With so many different products that have different storage and shipping needs, it is difficult for a company to specialize in the entire scope of the industry's product offerings. Instead, industry companies operate on a regional basis with a limited number of distribution facilities based in a single area. Industry companies may also specialize in one corner of the industry, focusing on only one or a few product types.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: During the outlook period, residential construction is expected to decline due to caution on the part of home builders and investors. While the housing market has been growing robustly since the pandemic, construction markets are expected to slow as investors fear an increase in interest rates and falling demand for homes. As a result, the value of residential construction will likely decline at an annualized rate of 0.9% over the five years to 2027, while housing starts fall an annualized 1.7% during the same period.

However, while declines in the residential construction market may limit industry revenue over the next five years, increased nonresidential construction is anticipated to present an opportunity for the industry. In fact, the value of nonresidential construction will likely grow at an annualized rate of 1.8% over the five years to 2027. However, the effects of this growth will be limited because nonresidential buildings typically use lower cost floor coverings. Some consumers do not use floor coverings, such as more durable carpeting or linoleum.

Over the next five years, as the Carpet and Floor Covering Distributors industry begins to stabilize and stagnate, the number of companies will also stagnate. With limited opportunities for growth, companies are not likely to enter the industry. However, stabilization from downstream markets is also expected to support steady profit, making companies less likely to exit the industry. In 2027, industry profit, measured as earnings before interest and taxes, is expected to account 3.8% of revenue, down slightly from 3.9% in 2022.

industry_definition: This industry sells carpet and floor covering to other wholesalers and retailers. Companies in this industry do not manufacture the products they distribute.

mixed_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level: medium - increasing

key_trends: Distributors were forced to reduce prices in the wake of the pandemic
Declining disposable income may lead to increased demand for industry products
The industry experiences high demand for employees to manage client relations
Declining demand in downstream markets may threaten industry revenue
Consumers will likely increase spending on home renovations to raise the value of their homes
Industry wages are expected to stagnate while employment increases

market_segmentation.segment_description: Retailers represent the largest market for carpet and floor covering distributors and include hardware stores as well as big box and department stores.

Residential construction represents a significant market for carpet and floor covering distributors because new homes and apartments typically need carpeting, linoleum, wood tile or other floor covering products.
Other markets for industry products include other wholesalers that may repackage industry products.

Nonresidential construction represents a significant market for the industry. Nonresidential construction projects include offices, retail space, health facilities and other privately-owned establishments.
Other markets for industry products include government construction projects and individuals working on large home renovations.

products_and_services.product_description: Carpets and rugs represent the largest product segment in the industry and includes installed carpets such as rolled carpet and carpet tile, as well as rugs or all sizes and styles.
The industry's second-largest single category product segment is wood flooring. This segment includes wood paneling or tiles that are installed on top of an existing floor.
Aside from carpet and wood, floor coverings can be made from a wide variety of materials, including ceramic, linoleum, rubber and vinyl.

tier_1_suppliers: Household Furniture Manufacturing in the US
tier_1_buyers: Floor Covering Stores in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Demand for the Carpet and Floor Covering Distributors industry is driven by several factors, but the most significant determinant is the state of residential construction. New buildings often use some kind of flooring other than concrete or hardwood, so as construction increases, so does demand for industry products.

business_locations.location_description: The West region is the most concentrated region in the industry, accounting for an estimated 24.0% of establishments in 2022. This is likely due to a combination of population and access to imports.
The Southeast region accounts for 25.9% of the population and is home to an estimated 23.7% of industry establishments in 2022.

The Mid-Atlantic region, despite having a lower population, is estimated to account for 21.2% of establishments in 2022, possibly due to better access to ports for importing floor coverings from overseas manufacturers.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Like other wholesaling industries, companies in the industry are required to obtain wholesale licenses to be able to legal operate in the United States.
While more regulations are placed on manufacturers, industry companies must ensure the products they distribute are safe.
The Consumer Product Safety Improvement Act of 2008 requires that carpets and rugs sold in the United States must comply with flammability standards.

Similar to most industries, the COVID-19 pandemic disrupted operations for nearly all operators, with various local, state and federal pandemic-related regulations affecting industry enterprises' ability to operate.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The most significant of these barriers is the initial start-up costs. Entering any wholesale industry requires significant investment, due to the high cost of acquiring an inventory, and this industry is no exception.
It can also be difficult for new companies to establish contracts with manufacturers, given the large number of companies already in the industry, and consolidation in the manufacturing industry.

Additionally, due to changing consumer preferences and declining downstream demand from the Construction sector, the industry is currently in a state of decline, leaving few opportunities for new companies.

basis_points.basis_title: Competition based on price, product variety and quality
basis_points.basis_description: Internally, industry companies compete based on price, product variety and product quality.

basis_points.basis_title: Regional operations to avoid high shipping costs
basis_points.basis_description: Due to the high cost of shipping carpets and floor coverings long distances, industry companies mainly operate regionally to avoid raising prices.
Additionally, companies compete for contracts from manufacturers because there is a limited number of carpet and floor covering manufacturers.
Externally, the industry competes with manufacturers that sell directly to retailers and customers.

basis_points.basis_title: Competition from alternatives to carpets and floor coverings
basis_points.basis_description: Externally, the industry competes with alternatives to carpets and floor coverings.
Industry companies are threatened by changing consumer preferences, as industry revenue declines when consumer demand for carpet declines in favor of hardwood floors.

basis_points.basis_title: Competition based on styles and price points
basis_points.basis_description: Different styles of rugs and carpets carry different price points and move in and out of fashion.

concentration_points.concentration_title: No company has more than 5% market share
concentration_points.concentration_description: While some large companies are able to command large market shares within certain regions, at the national level, no company accounts for more than 5.0% of industry revenue in 2022.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Variety of industry products limits concentration
concentration_points.concentration_description: This is due in part to the large variety of industry products. While some industry companies specialize in rugs or other movable floor coverings, others provide installed wall-to-wall carpeting.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Labor represents the second-largest cost for the industry, with wages accounting for an estimated 9.0% of industry revenue in 2022.
Purchase expenses, including the cost of industry products, packaging materials and other supplies, represent the largest share of industry revenue.
Rent includes the cost of property, specifically, the cost of the distribution facilities out of which the industry operates.
Other costs for the industry include legal expenses, research and development and administrative fees.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Companies in this industry need employees to manage customer relations, complete sales orders and maintain distribution facilities. Meanwhile, capital expenditure is relatively low for the industry, with most revenue going toward the purchase of carpets and floor coverings.

While automation has increased over the five years to 2022, with advancements in supply chain management software and online POS systems, increases in average wages have enabled labor costs to outpace capital expenditure.
In 2022, for every $1.00 spent on labor, industry companies are expected to spend an estimated $0.06 on capital.
Over the next five years, as these systems continue to advance, capital intensity is expected to grow slightly as demand for labor begins to wane.

volatility_points.volatility_description: This heightened volatility is largely due to the COVID-19 pandemic, which caused downstream demand to fall and then sharply rise in 2020 and 2021, respectively.
Demand for carpets and floor coverings is driven by residential construction, home renovations and disposable income.

Housing starts surged following the pandemic, as the economy quickly recovered and more people began moving away from cities and into suburban areas. This caused revenue to rise because new homes need either carpeting or rugs and other floor coverings.

However, as home prices have sharply increased and disposable income levels have begun to decline in 2022, revenue is expected to begin declining again, further increasing the level of overall volatility.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: While wholesaling industries have experienced some advances in supply chain management software and online ordering systems, these changes have been relatively minimal and have not drastically changed industry operations.
The most significant effect of these innovations has been a slow push toward automation, as inventory management software can reduce the need for employees to keep manual logs of supplies.
Carpet technology has not changed significantly over the past five years. Stain resistant, hypoallergenic and machine washable carpets and rugs have been the focus of innovation in recent years.
